participants.participant: Hans Dieter Pötsch, Member of the Board of Management, Finance and Controlling
Detlef Wittig, Executive Vice President, Group Sales and Marketing
Christine Ritz, Group Head of Investor Relations

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Volkswagen Conference Call for the first six Months of 2008. I'm joined today by Hans Dieter Pötsch, Member of the Board of Management, Volkswagen AG responsible for Finance and Controlling; and by Detlef Wittig, Executive Vice President, Volkswagen AG, responsible for Group Sales and Marketing.

As usual, you can also follow the webcast and download the chart from our website www.volkswagenag.com/ir. Questions can be sent by e-mail or called in. Before we start, I would like to mention that our after the speech of Mr. Pötsch and Mr. Wittig, we will first respond to the questions of analysts and later answer those of journalists.
I would now like to ask Mr. Pötsch to give a few comments on the highlights of the first half of 2008 before Mr. Wittig goes into detail of the deliveries to customer. Mr. Pötsch, please.

Thanks a lot ladies and gentlemen, also a warm welcome from my side to this conference call. I'm very pleased to be here today to discuss our continued good performance. As I last spoke to you in April, global economic trends have certainly become more of a concern. I am therefore particularly delighted to announce that not only have our sales outperformed market, but we were able translate these into a strong improvement our operating result.

Our operating profit increased significantly by 21.8%, €3.4 billion in the first half of 2008. Consolidated pre-tax profit also increased strongly by 25.5%, to €3.8 billion. Despite the challenges of higher raw material and energy costs, we have continued reduce our product cost. First half, our CapEx ratio lies at 4.3%, continued to invest in our new models, Powertrain as well as new facilities in Russia and India, our CapEx will rise up to 6% this year.
Good sales performance and profit delivered thus far in 2008 and our expectations for the second half has given us confidence, reaffirm our goal of improved sales and profitability 2008.
I will give you a few more details on our financial performance later on. Let me now hand over to Wittig who will give you an overview our positive sales development.

Thank you and welcome also from my side ladies and gentlemen. On the first chart I can show you left column the Volkswagen Group sales results which is as far as deliveries to customers are concerned, new sales record for us with an increased rate of 5.8% against last year were now up 3.26 million vehicles. Likewise during the same period the world car market increased by only 1%, so that simply results in gaining market share on our side.

Now looking at the individual brands of the Group from left to right. First, the Volkswagen Passenger Cars also a new record, sales record. Equally – equal to the performance of the total Group, an increased rate of 5.8% up to 1.9 million cars. And this growth from the Volkswagen brand cycle is certainly driven by our results in China, in Russia, Brazil and also a positive development in the German market.
Audi Sales were up by 1.4% up to 516,000 cars, the best first half year in Audi's history. That was certainly driven by the new A4 and the new A5.

Škoda continued it's very positive trend with a further, further strong plus of 17.9%, up till now 367,000 units and highlights as far as this quarter performance is concerned certainly the market entry in China. And an 80% increase in Russia, up to 24,000 units in the first half of the year.

SEAT, however suffered a decline of 7.5%. But taking into account the very difficult Spanish market that was down by 17% in the first half year and also the Italian market, and the Audi Ibiza in the run-up phase, this is from our point of view still a reasonably good performance. We will see more then from SEAT in the second half.
Bentley was down 16.5% and that compares with the first half year of 2007, where we saw high demand therefore the launch of the Bentley GT. We expect also a more balanced demand then for Bentley.

Our Commercial Vehicles continued had a excellent development in the first half year with deliveries to customers increasing by 12.9%, up to 264,000 units, all model lines there contributed to the success also in all areas in the world.

Now turning to the deliveries to customers by area, by market area. This chart shows the two columns to your right, steep increase rates for the South American market 12.4% and Asia-Pacific 20.00 -- 21.5%. So those areas were driving our sales volume.

Europe now starting from left, in Europe our deliveries increased to 1.96 million units, up to 1.7%, but we had to separate a little bit the European areas into Western Europe and Central and Eastern Europe. As far as Western Europe is concerned, we saw a decline – a slight decline of our sales by minus of 1.2% because of the very weak total markets in Italy and Spain. And in contrast, we had a good sales performance in Germany and the UK.

Germany in our domestic market we reached a record market share of 32.7%. The contrast program shown in Central and Eastern Europe where we saw an increase of deliveries by 18.7% and this is certainly driven by the two markets, Russia where we increased our sales by 63% and Ukraine.

Then into North America, though we had a decrease of 3.8% as compared with last year's period, therein is the United States where we almost flattened our sales volume which is a different trend comparing version in the United States with the Volkswagen brand however showing a remarkable – a slight increase of close to one where we saw a decline because of market situation there.

Now turning North America, positive trend here is driven by Brazil and Argentina. Brazil was up – our sales in Brazil were up by 22% and in Argentina . However, hidden in these figures is South Africa where we saw a decline – a drastic fall of the total market by some 20% of our sales .

Very favorable situation Asia-Pacific, we saw our sales practically going up by another 21% and this is due to strong growth that we enjoyed and still enjoy in China with 23% and also in India where we started now first steps Volkswagen in the market after Skoda – growth rate there of 70% .

Now would like to show you a comparison of the development of the world car market, the total world market by area and comparing it with our sales performance in these respective area. You can see up there North America, where we saw as car market, the total market declining in the first half year by minus 8.5%. Although we did much better, yes, we saw a decline of our sales by minus 3.8%, but in relation to the total market then that shows that we are gaining strength and that we are gaining market share.
Western Europe, the total market also went down by 2.6%. We did better, yes, we saw a minus 1% and at the same time the market share increased for the Group – for our Group in Western Europe.

Then turning toward the more dynamic markets, the famous BRIC markets, Eastern Europe and Russia in there. The car market very dynamic total market went up by 30%, we went up by 35% in Russia as I mentioned or even by 63%.

South America also dynamic, a very dynamic the car market there, plus 16% for the car market but plus 18% for us. And there in is Brazil with 22% increase of sales. So we are gaining market share in South America. Asia-Pacific, that includes China, India and Japan, certainly the market went up by 10.5%. So it's not that dynamic anymore but still growing. We had the chance of gaining 21% more than last year, so we make – we increase our penetration in the Asia-Pacific area.
So we gain market share, our world market share actually as we can count it went up close to 10% -- 9.9%. So we are gaining -- we are getting closer to our --

Turning to a few highlights on new models for our various brands. First of all, Volkswagen Scirocco shown here, had an excellent reaction from journalists and dealers since the first showing at the Geneva Motor Show. The Scirocco was accepted as the affordable dream car combines exciting expressive design and pure enjoyment of drive. And we will launch the car this year local in the markets here in Europe, end of August.
The positive volume effects for the Volkswagen brands resulted also from the North America and in China, and the Sagitar, Bora base.

Tiguan – again mentioning the Tiguan with almost 50,000 deliveries first half year for the very good performance. We are looking forward now to introducing the Passat CC in June and the Golf – and the new Golf generation end of October.

Now turning to Audi. As mentioned before, Audi reported the best first half year in its history. Success is certainly the result of the renovation of the model lineup and the enlargement of the product portfolio. And the Audi A4 Avant shown here picture, has enjoyed great success. Matching our customer's requirements, Audi design oriented stationary. The A4 sedan introduced at the end of last year already performed very strongly with sales going up 30%.
Equally successful was the A4, A5 Coupé of which we have delivered almost 27 .

Škoda, the Škoda brand continued the success during the first half year and I've mentioned the 17.9% increase rate already, the picture here shows the new Superb. The Superb was introduced last month on the European markets and was certainly a contributor to the ongoing success of the brand, the picture here shows the intelligent Twindoor concept for the rear hatch allowing easy access to the huge trunk compartment.

China has started production of the Fabia in the second half of last year, pushed the deliveries for the first half year 2008 up to 33,000 cars and that was major push also for the sales volume of the Škoda worldwide. And then we will start in the second half year in October, second model for Škoda.

Now SEAT. As mentioned before, we had a minus of 7.5% but that is really due to the very weak home markets Spain and also the weak total market in Italy and the run-out of the Audi Ibiza. This chart here shows the new Ibiza. The new Ibiza went on sale in May and we will compliment the range to the Coupe 3.0 version in July. We'll see the new design here what we call the aero design, sporty and innovative car, full of character, high precession and quality and we expect turnaround certainly for the Ibiza, for SEAT, and to start a new chapter in quality and in profitability for the brand.
Thank you, Mr. Wittig. Mr. Pötsch, can you take us through the financials please.

Yes of course I can. And let's get started with the sales revenues. Sales revenue which as you know excludes our Chinese joint ventures which we report within the equity results, in financial results increased by 3% or 1.6 – rose to €56.5 billion.

Volume growth generated a positive 2.2 billion. Pricing added a further 0.5. While mix currency, that's mainly the U.S. dollar and British pound reduced overall growth. Financial services added a further €0.5 billion.

Now let me now turn to operating profit. Price, mix and volume contributed a positive €0.5 billion. We had a negative impact after hedging of €0.4 billion from currencies and it's mainly the U.S. dollar and British pound.

Despite the headwinds of further increases in quality prices, our continued efforts move to cost of our vehicles resulted in the saving of €0.5 billion in product costs. Fixed cost (16;37) made stable while lower depreciation moves by capital efficiency of the last year's offset higher cost related expansion revenue of .
Financial services continues to weather the storm in financial markets and despite higher funding cost remains slightly ahead of last year's first half earnings.

Now let me turn to cash flow. In the automotive division cash flow from operating activities was €5.1 billion. Cash flow from investing activities stood at 2.8 billion, excluding our investment in MIM, 2007 among others, investments rose by 653 million reflecting our investment in power train products and new facilities.

As we commented in first quarter, earlier years we have taken significant steps to achieve the sustainable improvement in our working capital. Whilst we continue to maintain a firm hand on purse strings, such an improvement cannot be repeated each year.

In addition, our success in increasing sales also leads to higher inventory as we insure our network has sufficient supply. Following our normal seasonality pattern, our CapEx ratio at 4.3% is expected to climb towards 6%..

Cash flow from operating activities exceeds our investments by €2.3 billion, contributing to further increase automotive debt liquidity which ended the period at €15.1 billion, 1.6 billion over our 2007 year-end ratio.

Now let's take a look at financial performance of the different brands. Positive sales development binding with further improvements in our cost efficiency, led to strong improvement in the operating result of Volkswagen Passenger Car brand, Audi and Volkswagen Commercial Vehicle. Škoda's earnings increased by 7%, 381 million underperforming to growth of 11.7% sales due to the impact of the strong Czech crown. With new EBITDA, shared renewal of its product portfolio is emerging, however faced with dramatic drop in the Spanish market, faces the stiff near term challenge. Ability to remain in the black, recording 2 million for the first half is testament to the hard work of the entire sales team.

Finally, our Chinese business has continued its excellent progress both in sales and in earnings, recording a proportional operating profit of €184 million, more than double the performance of the first half 2007.

Ladies and gentlemen, we noted a number of you on the call today are concerned about the outlook for the global economy and to auto sector. I believe the Volkswagen Group is well positioned for the current economic climate. Both Mr. Wittig and myself will now take a few moments of your time to outline the challenges we see and strategies as adopted that will ensure we can conquer them.

Well when I look at the external challenges and the chart with the first three challenges here, global demand slowing, engine consumer priorities and ignition regulations. Certainly clear for all of us that the global economy is slowing down from the strong growth last couple of --

But I would like to underline, we still see growth across our global sales in 2008 and beyond. But as I mentioned earlier with a regard to our sales performance so far in 2008, we cannot see a clear split between the so-called developed markets and the emerging market. If you sort of add up the volume increase of the first half year, that certainly comes from the emerging markets and not from the developed market where we are going into.

Secondly, the surge in the oil price, its volatility may lead new car buyers to consider more economical smaller cars and or smaller engine. We can clearly see this strength not only in the U.S. market but also in Europe. And there is concern for the environment. Yes, leading on the other hand to a wide range in Europe of 15 different national taxation regimes analyzing CO2 emissions and this diverse push to emission regulations in Europe is certainly a further burden impacting customer choices.

If uncertainty as to what the different national takes will look like is perhaps the most occupation. There are not only challenges but there are also opportunities and as far as emissions are concerned in consumption, fuel consumption is concerned; we certainly worked early on these challenges with solutions and maybe too early ahead of their time. The aluminum Audi A2, and the 3.0-liter Lupo. I guess we have confidence in developing.

Our modern diesel engines today, technologically leading TSI gas engines in our current BlueMotion range of cars for the Volkswagen brand and similar ranges, equal ranges for all our brands have built on this. We offer customers a range of class leading fuel efficient engines without compromising comfort. Combined with our DSG gearbox, we offer excellent .

I have already mentioned the BRIC market. Our push into the markets of India and Russia, for instance, our sales are growing at an exceptionally fast pace, ahead of the opening of our new factories in .
Our leading positions in China and in Brazil will be a market leader, allows us to profitably tap the enormous growth taken.
Also we transfer the lessons learned from our success to the newer markets will allow us to consolidate our .

I would also like to underline the contribution of our financial services. Financing, the second question when buying a new car. I am delighted that we have such an excellent company supporting our business, fantastic range of product.

So summarizing challenges and opportunities, yes I'm of course concerned with the global economic trends passing their shadow on a number of car markets in the world but I believe we have the right products, we have the right technology, we are all -- we are well supported by our financial services colleagues. Now our brands are trusted as high quality innovative brands by our customers . We are sure we can ride out the storm and we will continue to delight ever more customer – our products.

So allow me now to focus on some of the other challenges. You are all familiar with the strong euro and the unprecedented weakness of the U.S. dollar not only is this a concern for our U.S. business but for all our U.S. dollar denominated .

Newspapers are full of stories surrounding the price of steel and oil based commodities and rising interest rates, very turbulent market I think not only on the customer side but clearly impact the cost of funds for our industrial and financial service activities. So how we position?

We have announced our plans to open a factory in the U.S. in 2011, this will complement our assembly and powertrain activities Mexico, buying with exports to other markets will substantially depress, balance our U.S. dollar exposure. Short-term, we have substantial hedging in place will provide good protection and will help smooth exchange rate impact.

Hedging on commodities will provide some help, too. Our colleagues in purchasing our working spread outs together with our engineers to reduce our costs yet further from the €0.5 billion I announced earlier. Our new initiative for the tool kit developed from Audi at the future of their tool box for transversal engines for Volkswagen other brands will provide further constant leap our cost saving effort.

Only the scale we gain will lead further double-digit percentage saving in the cost as well as engine investment in the engineering area. Although we cannot rule out some impact from inflation affected to commodities we use to build our cars, I am convinced we still have a huge potential further cost savings.

Couple of these activities to Volkswagen weigh our initiatives mainly in the manufacturing arena delivering savings up 10% in productivity per annum. This will continue funding for our financial services activities is of course more expensive than before but we have been able to minimize the impact wide range of funding tools. And as I have often said, our strong cash balance underlies the strength of our automotive balance sheet, giving us the means finance growth internally while still keeping some back for a rainy day.

As Mr. Wittig commented, buying with our potential to delight even more customers with our products, but costs, investments, remain firmly under control with hard work we can look forward to the future with confidence.

And this leads us to our 2008 outlook. First half was a good result. Our strategy has proved to be the right one or to current environment. Customers continue to buy our cars at an increasing rate directed by the exciting design of our cars, our efficient powertrains and our excellent quality. Reaffirming what I said to you on the Q1 conference call, thanks to higher sales revenue coming from the expected increase in unit sales, together with our efficiency and productivity improvements, our operating profit for 2008 will be listed above the previous year's figure.

Continue to expect a positive net cash flow and a further improvement in the automotive division's liquidity position. As noted this point that this is before taking into account the effects of our acquisition of further shares in Scania. We raised our share in voting rights to 68.6% on the 22nd of July which was yesterday when the key anti-trust approvals were granted.

This enables us to consolidate the Scania as our 9th successful brand. After consideration of the effect of purchase price allocation, we expect Scania to make some slightly positive earnings contribution Volkswagen Group in the second half of the year.
Mr. Pötsch, thank you very much. We will now move to the Q&A session starting with the first questions of analysts.
Our first question will come from Jochen Gehrke from Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon. I have three questions actually for me. First of all Mr. Pötsch, I think we all noted in the first half a very sharp decline in depreciation in the industrial business, I wonder whether you could comment on that is this the trend that we should expect for the full year hence in the level of reduction in H1 just multiplied by two. Or is there any different seasonality in that?

Secondly, Mr. Wittig, regarding China yesterday, AutoLive was more cautious with regards to this market for the fourth quarter, is this also something that you expect to happen in terms of remarkable slowdown in growth at least in the Chinese market for the rest of the year?

And thirdly, Mr. Pötsch, most recently you commented on raw materials and steel, citing that Volkswagen has three to five -year contract so seeing no problem, I wonder whether you could give us an update, have you seen any renewed attempt by steel makers to break these contracts and what's your take on that with regards to raw material price inflation on P&L VW? Thank you.
Well, thank you very much. Jochen Gehrke has three questions for us. For the first question is about depreciation and if you can give some more information and an outlook for 2008.

The next question is for Mr. Wittig with regards to China which -- what development we expect for the full year, do we expect any slowdown? And the third question is about raw materials, if we can give some more information about the impact of steel, if he can give you some more information. Thank you.

Yeah, I will start answering the second question where China is concerned. Well, we have seen the Chinese market expanding this year by 14% but that's a mixture already off the first quarter. The first quarter the market went up by 20%, in the second quarter slowed down with an increase rate of only 9%. So we do see already a slowing down, certainly influenced by the earthquake and the floods but also the starting -- seeing an impact of the credit squeeze measures of the government. So we will see a further sort of a softening of the market in the second half year. But we still expect that the Chinese market will be somehow 10 to 12% above last year in total this year. So through the growth but softening of the growth, yes.

Well, I'm continuing on the question of depreciation. Very clearly speaking if you look at the balance sheet, it's very obvious that on the basis of very disciplined investment policy in the past. We are now enjoying a reasonable number in terms of depreciation, in line with our forecast that we see the CapEx sales ratio coming up step-by-step that is going to change but clearly not to any significant way this year.

The second question on raw material contracts. I must have missed the quote that I ever said we would have no problem at all. The fact situation is that we are reasonably projected short-term. And that specifically given for 2008, but it's some dates clearly and after some time, we will also be hit by what's currently taking place in raw material markets and that's why clearly we also have to prepare for a situation when all the effects which are currently registered on the spot markets will have their effect on our bottom-line. How we can handle this that's clear.
So can we have the next question please?
We will now move to Albrecht Denninghoff from BHF Bank. Please go ahead.

Yes, hello. First, two housekeeping questions regarding the shipment products and the production schedule, could you tell us how much were your production figures for China? And this also increased quite exponentially or did you have already a slowing production rate in China? That would be effect the first question.

And second question as your reduction was considerably stronger in the second quarter as your shipments. Could you tell us what the effect from the P&L is? Could you confirm that it's not significantly higher than €150 on the improved fixed costs results effect from the higher production than the shipment network? Thanks.

Okay. Thank you very much. Albrecht Denninghoff had two questions for us. The first question is about shipments and production figures for China. And the second one is again about strong development of production in the second quarter and if you can give some further information about the effects on our P&L? Thank you.

Maybe a little bit principal comment at this point, you will recognize when you look at the yearend numbers of 2007 that our stock situation was not as we would put it ideal. We were missing a number of cars in terms of the overall volume on stock and also of course, we are missing a number of specific models. So what we were trying to do in the first half was to compensate this to a certain part. Unfortunately, we still have to say in a number of areas we are not satisfied with what we were able to achieve for the simple reason that we were selling with a higher frequency than what we predicted some months ago. So some adjustments have to be taken still. Though we could say, we think with these exceptions in mind, we are prepared for the second half of the year but there is no significant impact to the P&L by the fact that production was high -- was running higher.
Okay. Next question please.
Our next question will come from from HSBC. Please go ahead.

from HSBC, good afternoon. Three questions if I may. Firstly, I have seen your other operating profits in the automotive divisions; it's up by €319 million in the second quarter year-on-year. That asset was still flat in Q1 2008 year-on-year. So I ask myself what is the reason behind that, may you give some explanation on that.

Then second question that I have is on SEAT. If you also said SEAT turned negative again in the second quarter. I know you have ambitious plans regarding model launches at SEAT this year and also next year. But please can you give some update what you expect from SEAT if Spanish car market remains at peak and new models really lead SEAT into sustainable profitable situation.
And then third question is on Scania, I know that you consolidated Scania, may be you can give us some information what you expect in terms of PPA depreciation here going forward. Thank you.

Okay. Thank you very much. has two -- three questions for us. The first question is about the other operating profit, if you can give some further update for the Automotive division? And then the second question is about SEAT, if you can give some information which development do we expect for SEAT now that the Spanish market is quite weak. And the third question is about the consolidation of Scania, if you can give some more details on that, thank you.

Well to the first question in terms of other operating income, the main driver behind the positive development there is the effect coming out of our cash flow hedges in terms of currency. And while we show the fair valuation of the total volume of our contract in our equity position without affecting the P&L, once we release the basic business then of course we also release the respective forwards.

And in the second quarter, we were reasonably successful there. Of course there is no side of the coin which is that the exchange rates to somewhat were going well specifically as far as the British pound and the dollar were concerned. And that's creating a significant positive impact, that's why although the exchange rate effect in our swing factor analysis from the operating profit last year to this year was -- is shown with 400 million negative. It's clear that if the real exchange rates would have been effective, that number would have been dramatically higher. So we were fortunately heavily protected against this. That's the main effect on other operating profit.

A word on SEAT, yes of course SEAT had a bit of a difficult second quarter for the simple reason first of all that as we were able to show the Spanish market dropped quite significantly, and significant part of the SEAT business of course is taking place in Spain. The second point is very clearly that we are just in the middle of changing from the former Ibiza model to the new Ibiza model.

The good thing there is that we got very positive comments from the press and the first customers about the cars that makes us very positive as far as the future is concerned. Nevertheless, it takes some time until we ramp up production into cars fully available. And that's why the second quarter is shown not in a sufficient way. Over the full year we are still positive that SEAT will realize a positive operating result above the year 2000 ever.
Sorry, can I raise an add-on question here?
Let me just finish on that please.
Okay, sorry.

And then to as far as Scania is concerned, it's a little bit premature to talk about single effects coming out of purchase price accounting, that's why we thoughtfully choose the formula to save to give you a little bit an orientation on what you could potentially factor in your models is that taking the performance of Scania for the second half and potential effects coming out of purchase price accounting, most probably we'll end up with a only slightly positive result.
Now you had another question.

Yeah, it's particularly regarding SEAT. I agree with you certainly regarding 2008 because EBITDA is also positioned in the second which is probably growing in light of the – light of crude prices but when I look into the SEAT pipeline for 2009, I see that you are planning to launch here maybe then a D segment car or rather automated cars which are rather high fuel consuming, and so I get some doubts if they could really be a success in the market, given the higher oil prices and given the fact that the Spanish car market is in such a weak situation and is that – I like to ask myself what is happening with SEAT and really in the long term so beyond 2008.

Now a quick answer to that that. There's no reason to put any question mark to the SEAT strategy for the simple reason that yes you are right, we will introduce also bigger car next year but it's very clear as the focus markets for this car are more in -- specifically also the southern part of Europe, it goes without saying that the car will be powered by very fuel efficient engines and that's why that's not a contradiction to the most recent trends in the market and of course it's not creating any question mark to the SEAT strategy.
Okay. Thank you very much.
Can we take the next question please?
The next question is from John Lawson from Citigroup. Please go ahead.

Thanks very much and good afternoon all. First question referring back to the earlier answer on raw materials, I wonder has Volkswagen created any explicit goal of recovering raw material costs from the customers with price rises? Basically, what do you think of that as a strategy?

Second question, we don't seem to hear much anticipation of the new Golf in terms of enhancing your returns. If we go back a little bit in history, this was seen as a major step forward. I wonder whether there were any specific hopes on the cost or revenue side that you can share with us for this model as it comes in the final quarter of the year.

And then finally for Mr. Wittig, I suppose, if we put together all of the BlueMotion and echo ranges that you're selling to the market today, could you give us an idea of what proportion of sales they're currently representing? Could you tell us how fast you might hope to build those up or do you suppose that in time BlueMotion will simply become your mainstream product? Thank you.

Okay. Thank you very much. John Lawson has three questions for us. First question is about the impact of raw materials on our earnings and if we consider any price increases for our car? The second question is about the Golf, if you can give some more information on cost and revenue side for this year? And the third quarter is about echo ranges which we offer to our customers and what proportion of the total sales they have and if that will be our – in the future our mainstream product? Thank you.

Well, regarding your question as to potential price hikes. First of all, when we listen to the market and listen to our competitors we see a number of announcements that also our competitors are scared because of the price hikes on raw materials and also they are confronted some of them with a higher Euros in the foreign business. So from that point of view the industry doesn't seem to be able to compensate all the raw material price hikes and the challenges from exchange rates to rationalization programs only. So there is a trend in the market that we may have to pass on some of these cost increases to the customer.

We are reviewing the situation as well, we need to know more specifics as to what finally will be the cost increase that is hitting us, but yes; we will also certainly not be able to compensate all of these price increases. So we have actually discussing whether we should pass on some of these price hikes to our customers and the question being, it is we are acting in a very competitive market actually. So we have to watch our competition as well. But as I can see and feel it from the temperature in the market, there seem to be some price hikes in the second half of this year going to the market to our customers.

Maybe I can continue with your question regarding new Golf. First of all to be honest I think the current car deserves a positive remark because without any doubt it turned out to be extremely competitive and stable in the volume it produced and since quite a while we have improved the returns, of course, still a level or to a level which is not completely satisfying. But I think that the car which really that turned out to be by far the most successful one in the segment deserves some positive remark.

So let me have a few comments on the new Golf of course, as we were all saying, we need to change a couple of things on the cost side, that's all done and in spite of the cost increases coming from the commodity side and also out of other areas, the car shows a significant improved cost basis. That should not mean that we would offer the car for a lower price than the existing car that would be a wrong interpretation and that means taking everything together the return of the new car right from the beginning will be significantly better.

And of course, looking at the volume of the new Golf, it is one of the pillars for the continuation of the positive performance of Volkswagen without any doubt, and it's clearly one of the reasons why we are in a position to say well, primary conditions clearly did not turn to the positive in the last couple of months but we still stick to our commitments for this year and also for further years.
Thank you.

Well as far as the question of BlueMotion range is concerned, I can tell you that as far as the Volkswagen range is concerned we are selling in Europe as something like 7, 8% of the total volume as BlueMotion models very successful in there certainly Golf and all of BlueMotion models.

This is true also for our other brands, the Audi with the E8 models and Škoda with the GreenLine, and SEAT with the Ecomotive. So in total we have sold in Europe something like 70-80,000 cars in the first half year based on these echo models but that's not the whole story because we have to take into consideration the shift into the smaller fuel efficient TSI engines and also into some of our smaller and very efficient diesel engines and that altogether is a much higher number then.

That answers also the question whether some time we will see the BlueMotion models as the 100% of our Volkswagen, that's certainly not the case because we will work into our cars. We will design into our cars all the elements of the blue model versions today and there may be then a BlueMotion version number two someday when we have worked it through.
Thank you.
Okay, thank you. Next question please.
The next question comes from Christian Breitsprecher from Oppenheimer. Please go ahead.

Okay. Good afternoon, it's Christian Breitsprecher from Oppenheimer. I have three questions.
